messages.message: Thanks @Heymian, this is a great start to map our features/components to owners!
Can we also go ahead and add service owners on this doc? It will help when people have issues wrt a specific service and do not know who/which team to reach out.
i think for service we should have readme.md inside each service in the repo itself. this can capture service owners, nuances & caveats of the service deployment.
Agreed that should work as well

Hey, i did think about service owners briefly, and ended up leaving it off. I worry that “dividing” up ownership at the service level might encourage bad practices such as the loose creation of new services wherever there’s a new “feature”. We need to rethink our microservice division, because it is getting out of hand. I imagine that we should be able to unify more of them based on resourcing constraints rather than just functionality, in which case, there’ll be more shared ownership as many teams will work within the service.

I think some services might make sense, like dynamic proxy or webdriver, but api-server-apps or evening app-tasks seems odd. And also does owner mean infra owner or the code running in it, which might be different.

Thanks, these are great points, and agree with your thoughts around division of services. My initial suggestion around service owners stems from the fact that there are some services that do not have clear owners today.

Also imo the service owner can be multiple based on diff components/functions within it. And they should own the service e2e including infra aspects such as resourcing, scaling, replicas, deployment, jenkins etc in my opinion.
[The infra team (base-infra) provides ownership of shared infra components that get used when people use them in their services (ex: messaging, caching etc)]
